head.title: Ligand Insertion in MOF-74 as Effective Design for Oxidation of Ethane to Ethanol | The Journal of Physical Chemistry C

meta.content: Ligand Insertion in MOF-74 as Effective Design for Oxidation of Ethane to Ethanol

Efficient conversion of ethane into valuable materials is important with the availability of new natural gas resources. Recently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with open iron sites (i.e., Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74) have been shown to be promising material for catalyzing ethane to ethanol. In this computational study, various size-matching ligands are inserted into the Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74 structure to further optimize this reaction. Our density functional theory calculations show that the presence of ligands enhances the binding affinity of the oxygen atoms of N2O to the iron atoms in the framework, thereby leading to an improvement in the oxidizing process. Furthermore, the reaction pathways for the new structures show reduced enthalpy barrier in the rate-determining step in the oxidation of ethane reaction cycle compared to the original Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74. These findings provide ways in which the performance of the Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74 can be optimized for next-generation catalysts.

div.p:
Efficient conversion of ethane into valuable materials is important with the availability of new natural gas resources. Recently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with open iron sites (i.e., Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74) have been shown to be promising material for catalyzing ethane to ethanol. In this computational study, various size-matching ligands are inserted into the Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 structure to further optimize this reaction. Our density functional theory calculations show that the presence of ligands enhances the binding affinity of the oxygen atoms of N
2
O to the iron atoms in the framework, thereby leading to an improvement in the oxidizing process. Furthermore, the reaction pathways for the new structures show reduced enthalpy barrier in the rate-determining step in the oxidation of ethane reaction cycle compared to the original Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74. These findings provide ways in which the performance of the Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 can be optimized for next-generation catalysts.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Recently, converting natural gas into various industrially useful products has been viewed as an important problem within the catalyst community.
(1−5)
Given that natural gas is comprised mostly of methane, converting methane into useful products is very tempting. Unfortunately, this chemical conversion process is expensive due to the high dissociation energy associated with the C–H bond in the methane molecule.
(6)
Instead, many researchers have focused on the relatively less energy-intensive process of C–H activation in ethane, which is the second largest component of natural gas.
(1,7)
As such, many different materials, which include the Pt bidiazine complex,
(8,9)
zeolites,
(10−13)
and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs),
(14−17)
have been investigated in search for facile oxidation reaction of methane or ethane. Among these materials, MOFs with active metal sites are recognized for their potential application in reactions such as photocatalysis,
(18)
acylation/alkylation of aromatics,
(19,20)
cyanosilylation of aldehydes,
(18)
and oxidation of organic compounds.
(21)
More specifically, there are several research studies that focused on converting ethane into ethanol using MOFs that contain iron metal sites.
(14,15,17)
Xiao et al.
(14)
reported using Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 with open iron sites to catalyze the conversion of ethane to ethanol using N
2
O as an oxidant. Although electronic configuration with the high-spin
S
= 2 ground state is difficult to achieve in molecular compounds, Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 is an exception leading to facile activation of the C–H bonds of ethane, which can help convert ethane into ethanol. Inspired by this experiment, Verma et al.
(15)
used density functional theory (DFT) to investigate the mechanism behind this reaction pathway. And more recently, Liao et al.
(17)
conducted computational studies reporting the effect of the NH
2
groups attached to the linkers of the Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, which showed reduction of the enthalpy barrier for the rate-determining step in the reaction pathway from ethane to ethanol. Despite these important findings, there are still unresolved issues when it comes to this particular catalytic reaction, which include activation of N
2
O as an oxidizing agent and further reduction of the activation barrier. And unfortunately, the N
2
O molecule has poor σ-donating and π-accepting properties, which leads to an inefficient oxidation process.

To enhance the catalytic reaction of Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, we propose inserting size-matching ligands into the center of the MOF-74 framework to partition the original pore space.
(22)
In our previous computational work, we have shown that the ligand insertion strategy can be used to increase the working capacity of CO
2
under humid flue gas conditions.
(22)
Moreover, experimental work by Zhao et al.
(23)
has shown that insertion of 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligands in MIL-88 leads to enhanced CO
2
uptake in the Henry regime, creating strong CO
2
binding sites with the presence of the ligand. In the context of the catalytic reaction, this strategy was motivated by our hypothesis that the presence of ligand can lead to optimal binding configuration of N
2
O onto the metal, which can lead to more efficient reaction. Moreover, we anticipate that the ligand can help in the cleaving process of C–H bond with the benzene ring located in the center of the Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 structure acting to pull this bond in the opposite direction.

The paper is organized as follows. In the
Methodology
section, computational details of the quantum chemical calculations used in this work are described. In the
Results
section, the computational structures are described in detail, and the DFT data as well as analysis are presented. Finally, we summarize the important points in the
Conclusion
section.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
DFT calculations were performed to help understand the reaction mechanism of the catalytic oxidation of ethane. The periodic structures were fully optimized using periodic density functional theory as implemented in the Quantum Espresso.
(24)
From the initial optimized periodic structures, corresponding model clusters that contained three neighboring metal centers (along a single helical chain) and their first coordination spheres were carved out. All of the cluster calculations were performed with the Gaussian 09 software package.
(25)

Previously, Verma et al.
(15)
reported the details of the computational Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 structure obtained from density functional theory (DFT). Based on the previous study, the projected-augmented wave (PAW)
(26)
method was used to describe the electron–ion interactions, and for valence electrons a plane wave basis set was employed. The exchange-correlation effects have been described within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) using the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional.
(27)
The k-point mesh for these systems was selected as (2 × 2 × 1). A cutoff energy of 520 eV was found to be sufficiently large to provide convergent results.

All of the Kohn–Sham calculations were performed with the M06-L
(28)
exchange-correlation functional using the def2-TZVP
(29,30)
all-electron basis set. Prior work by Verma et al.
(15)
showed that the M06-L provides reasonable agreement with the multistate complete active space second-order perturbation theory (MS-CASPT2) for MOFs containing Fe. Using this functional, we can make direct comparisons with work by Verma et al.
(15)
Previous studies showed that the quintet
S
= 2 spin states in the Fe-MOF-74 cluster are most stable, and so we used
S
= 2 for structures reported in this study.

The ligand insertion of the MOF-74 structure can be a strategy to engineer the pore space to enhance the catalytic performance. As shown in
Figure
1
, the four different types of ligands ((1,3,5-tris(4-pyridyl)-2,4,6-triazine, 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene, 2,4-di(4-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-triazine, and 2,5-di-4-pyridinylpyrazine)) were computationally inserted within the hexagonal channels of MOF-74. To examine the effect of inserted ligands in more detail, we constructed a cluster with an 8 Å radius around the central Fe ion. A similar approach was taken by Verma et al.
(15)
in which they reported the 88-atom model by cutting a fragment from MOF-74. On the basis of the 88-atom model, we constructed a 108-atom model, which consists of the central Fe ion with three metal ions (see
Figure
2
). To examine the effect of the inserted ligands, the cluster was made slightly larger than previous model. With the exception of the Fe ion and the first coordination sphere, all atoms of the MOF cluster were constrained during the geometry optimization.

div.p: Figure 1. Illustration of pore space partitioned MOF-74 using size-matching regulated ligands 1,3,5-tris(4-pyridyl)-2,4,6-triazine (top left), 2,4-di(4-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-triazine (bottom left), 2,5-di-4-pyridinylpyrazine (top right), and 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene (bottom right).

Figure 2. Cluster model of Mg-MOF-74 with ligand inserted carved from its extended structure. The modification of the cluster model of Mg-MOF-74 with ligand inserted is representative Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 with ligand inserted. This cluster has the central Fe(II) metal site, and the other two metal sites are Mg(II). It is representative of Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 with ligand inserted. The calculations were performed at the Fe(II) metal sites where the numbers were written. (a) MOF structure with 1,3,5-tris(4-pyridyl)-2,4,6-triazine ligand inserted. (b) MOF structure with 2,4-di(4-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-triazine ligand inserted. (c) MOF structure with 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene ligand inserted. (d) Same as (c) but inserted ligand is 2,5-di-4-pyridinylpyrazine.

div.div:
The DFT binding energy of an individual gas molecule inside the MOF cluster was calculated as follows:
(1)
where
E
(MOF+gas),
E
(MOF), and
E
(gas) are the total DFT energy of the MOF with the gas molecule bound in the minimum-energy configuration, the total energy of the MOF structures, and gas molecule in the gas phase, respectively.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The insertion of 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligands into the hexagonal channels of Mg-MOF-74 and Zn-MOF-74 was demonstrated in our previous theoretical study of CO
2
capture under humid conditions.
(22)
In the previous work, the computed DFT binding energy of the tpt ligand was −302.1 kJ/mol in the Mg-MOF-74 structures, providing evidence that the ligands would stay intact and not wash away postsynthesis. The binding energy calculations of the other three ligands (dpt, bpb, and dpp) were performed in this work as additional calculations to confirm that the ligand would not wash away postsynthesis. In the periodic Mg-MOF-74 structure, the binding energies of dpt, bpb, and dpp ligand were computed to be −198.3, −187.6, and −219.75 kJ/mol, respectively. The binding energy results of the ligands at Fe-MOF-74 showed generally weaker values than those at Mg-MOF-74 (Table S1 in the
Supporting Information
). A cluster structure was constructed to calculate the catalytic reaction using this optimized structure. (
Figure
2
). When the ligand is inserted in the MOF, the metal site in which the reaction takes place as well as the surrounding environment might affect the reactions. For that reason, we created a 108-atom cluster that is larger than the 88-atom model studied by Verma et al.
(15)

Except for tpt-MOF, dpt-MOF and bpb-MOF contain different kinds of pores which exhibit different binding environments. The catalytic results can be different depending on where the reaction takes place in the divided pores. Therefore, we calculated for all of the numbered sites that represent the distinct sites where catalytic reactions can occur in
Figure
2
b–d.

div.h3:
N
2
O and C
2
H
6
Binding Energies
div.div:
N
2
O is used as the oxygen source to convert ethane into ethanol, and as such, the binding energy of N
2
O is an important factor that dictates successful catalysis. In the DFT calculations, we analyzed two different binding configurations with the “N direction”, indicating that the nitrogen atom of N
2
O binds with the Fe site while the “O direction”, indicating the opposite case (see
Table
1
).

Table 1. Binding Energies (in kJ/mol) for Nitrous Oxide Molecules in L-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 Structures (L = Ligand)
a

div.p:
The site numbers can be referred to in
Figure
2
(Δ
E
means energy differences between the N direction and the O direction).

div.div:
The binding energies for the N bind with Fe and O bind with Fe of N
2
O in Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 (the case of no ligand insertion) are −45 and −46 kJ/mol, respectively, indicating that the two orientations are equally likely (this was also shown in the studies by Xiao et al.
(14)
). On the other hand, all four MOFs with ligands showed significantly larger energy differences that favor the O direction over the N direction with Δ
E
= 15, 18, 14, and 14 kJ/mol respectively in tpt-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, dpt-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, bpb-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, and dpp-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74. To understand why this is the case, the conjugated molecular orbitals were compared between nitrogen of N
2
O toward the inserted ligand and oxygen of N
2
O toward the inserted ligand (dpt ligand used as an example) as shown in
Figure
3
.

div.p:
Figure 3. Schematic MO diagram to relative energies of the MOs when oriented toward nitrogen or oxygen of N
2
O molecule in the dpt ligand with N
2
O. Comparison between the energies of the HOMO levels of ligand bind with nitrogen of N
2
O and ligand bind with oxygen of N
2
O.

div.div:
More specifically, when the nitrogen of the N
2
O molecule binds toward the inserted ligand, the HOMO level of the conjugated system is stabilized because orbital populations of nitrogen maintain the dominant position in the LUMO level of the N
2
O molecule (coefficient: N(2.01) > O(0.55)). Therefore, the nitrogen prefers to make a significant contribution to the HOMO in the conjugated system (coefficient: O(0.96) > N(0.83)), thereby demonstrating that the oxygen of the N
2
O molecule binds toward the Fe metal sites in MOF, which enhances activation of N
2
O as an oxidizing agent. In
Table
1
, in all of the L-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 structures, N
2
O prefers to bind with the metal with the oxygen direction, which is promising for catalytic applications given that when the nitrogen of the N
2
O molecule binds toward the Fe site, N
2
O is unable to act as an oxidizing agent. Therefore, from the DFT results, we can conclude that there will be enhanced catalytic activity in these L-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 structures compared to the original Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 due to favorable binding configurations of N
2
O. In all other binding sites, we obtained similar trends for the L-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 structures as can be seen from Table S2 of the
Supporting Information
.

Next, we computed the interaction energy of ethane with tpt-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, dpt-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, bpb-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, and dpp-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 and obtained values of −45, −45, −46, and −43 kJ/mol, respectively (
Table
2
). The binding energy of ethane is generally weaker compared to N
2
O in MOF structures, as the difference in the ethane and the N
2
O binding energy is found to be 28 kJ/mol in dpt-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, which is extremely high and can thus ensure preferential binding with N
2
O in the presence of ethane. If the binding energy of the C
2
H
6
molecule is stronger than that of the N
2
O molecule, the N
2
O molecule cannot oxidize the metal sites in MOF. Therefore, this result shows that the oxidation reaction of ethane is more likely to occur in ligand inserted MOF-74 materials. The binding energy results in all sites show similar trends as can be seen in the
Supporting Information
(Table S3).

Table 2. Comparison with calculated N
2
O and C
2
H
6
Binding Energies (in kJ/mol) in L-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 Structures (L = Ligand)

div.h3: Reaction Mechanism of the Oxidation of Ethane
div.div:
The full reaction cycle studied in this work is depicted in
Figure
4
.

div.p:
Figure 4. Catalytic reaction cycle for ethane oxidation on an open Fe site. This mechanism is the same as proposed by Verma et al.
(15)

div.div:
The reaction has four transition states and seven intermediates. N
2
O adsorbs on the Fe(II) site (from “A” to “A-O” in
Figure
4
) and desorbs as N
2
(from “A” to “B” via TS1 in
Figure
4
). In the transition state (TS) 1, the cleavage of the N–O bond of N
2
O is the rate-determining step of the catalytic reaction studied for the MOF structure. After the iron(II) to iron(IV)–oxo conversion, the C–H bond of ethane is activated by the iron(IV)–oxo intermediate. The abstraction of the H atom from ethane by the iron(IV)–oxo results in the iron(III)–hydroxo species with a nearby ethyl radical (from “C” to “D” via TS2 in
Figure
4
). The rotation of the hydrogen atom of the hydroxo group along the Fe(III)–O(intermediate D) axis leads to intermediate E via TS3. The formation of ethanol (from “E” to “F” via TS4 in
Figure
4
) swerves to avoid the stereochemical hindrance from the H atom of the hydroxyl group. This rotation of the OH helps the radical rebound to form ethanol. The final process is the ethanol desorption which revert to the “A” structure (from “F” to “A” in
Figure
4
). Comparisons of our pathway to the pathway reported by Verma et al.
(15)
and the enthalpy changes along the reaction are presented in the
Supporting Information
(see section 1 and Figure S1). After the “D” configuration, various alternate pathways can resume after an alkyl radical is formed from an alkane. Therefore, two different competitive pathways, called desaturation and dissociation, were computed as well (see section 2 and Figure S2 in the
Supporting Information
).

In this catalytic reaction cycle, the highest endothermic steps are TS1, TS2, and desorption of ethanol. Therefore, we focused on these steps in the summarized analysis and compared against two other theoretical works with the original Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 (Verma et al.
(15)
) and NH
2
functionalized Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 (Liao et al.
(17)
) (
Figure
5
).

div.p:
Figure 5. Activation/desorption enthalpies of MOF-74
(15)
and functionalized MOF-74 with NH
2
(17)
obtained from previous works.

div.div:
Overall, TS1 is much lower (all under 70 kJ/mol) in the ligand inserted MOF-74 materials compared to the previously reported studies. As expected from the DFT binding energy and the MO data, the TS1, cleavage of the N–O bond of N
2
O, showed exceptionally low enthalpy with the insertion of the ligand for Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74. It is interesting note that the interaction between the ligand and N
2
O molecule affected the internal bond distance of N
2
O when N
2
O binds with metal sites in MOF.
Table
3
shows that the bond distance between the oxygen atom of the N
2
O and the center nitrogen atom of the N
2
O has increased from 1.25 Å that is the N–O internal bond distance of the N
2
O molecule in a vacuum to 1.31 Å inside the N
2
O molecule in tpt-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74. In the case of dpt-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, bpb-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, and dpp-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, similar trends are observed with the respective N–O distances of 1.30, 1.30, and 1.30 Å.

Table 3. Change of Internal Bond Distance of N
2
O Molecule in the Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 Structure with Ligand Inserted
a

div.p:
The DFT optimized calculation performed at the level of 6-31G(d,p). Comparison of bond length change when N
2
O binds with the metal site in L-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 structures (L = ligand).

div.div:
Similar to case for TS1, the TS2 step in which the C–H bond of ethane is activated by the iron(IV)–oxo intermediate showed decreased enthalpy with the ligand inserted MOFs compared to the original material. For the TS2 analysis, we focused on observing the relationship of the TS2 reduction between the ligand insertion and the HOMO energies (
Figure
6
).

div.p:
Figure 6. Schematic energy level diagrams of Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74
(15)
and functionalized Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 with NH
2
(17)
obtained from previous works. The energy levels of tpt-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, dpt-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, bpb-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, and dpp-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 were calculated in this work.

div.div:
Compared with Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, functionalizing the Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 linkers with NH
2
groups raises the TS2 enthalpy in the reaction cycle.
(17)
Previous work states that the electron-donating group functionalization of the linkers pushes up the Fe 3d orbitals and makes hydrogen abstraction more unfavorable. Combining this information with our finding, our results show that ligand with a benzene ring facilitates the π-donor effect, thereby raising the HOMO level. This trend is applicable for all the ligands as shown in
Figure
6
.

Unfortunately, the desorption enthalpy does not show much improvement compared to the two previous studies (Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 and amine-functionalized Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74), which might be due to the enhanced interaction between the ethane molecule and the newly inserted ligands. In the Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74 structure, TS1 was the rate-determining step in the catalytic cycle. However, it can be confirmed that the desorption process becomes the new rate-determining step in the MOF structures that contain the ligands (
Figure
5
). The tpt ligand shows higher desorption enthalpy compared to the other ligands, which seems to indicate that the reduced pore size is preventing the ethane from escaping. Consistent with this explanation, the dpp-Fe
0.1
Mg
1.9
-MOF-74, which consists of MOF with the smallest ligand, leads to the optimal enthalpy when it comes to the desorption step among the ligand inserted MOFs.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: In conclusion, we have shown that the ligand insertion strategy can reduce the barriers in ethane to ethanol conversion. In the ligand inserted MOFs, the cleaving a C–H bond of ethane and N–O bond of nitrous oxide becomes facilitated compared to the MOF without the ligand. Furthermore, other competitive pathways were explored, and we have shown that hydroxylation is more favorable reaction than dissociation and desaturation. These results for ligand inserted MOF clusters demonstrate that pore environments can be tuned to optimize the design for the novel catalysts for ethanol formation.

Natural gas (NG) is a naturally gaseous hydrocarbon mixt. that is formed under the earth's surface. NG is considered to be the cleanest fossil fuel and is a safe source of energy when transported, stored and used. The primary constituent of NG is methane, it may also contain (C2+ hydrocarbons, N2, CO2, He, H2S, and noble gases) according to its origin. Different gas processing technologies can be employed to remove constituents other than methane. Due to importance of NG as a fuel and the increasing global demand of it, this article reviews the fundamentals of NG origin, compn., and processing.

A review with 45 refs. The very large reserves of methane, which often are found in remote regions, could serve as a feedstock for the prodn. of chems. and as a source of energy well into the 21st century. Although methane currently is being used in such important applications as the heating of homes and the generation of hydrogen for ammonia synthesis, its potential for the prodn. of ethylene or liq. hydrocarbon fuels has not been fully realized. A no. of strategies are being explored at levels that range from fundamental science to engineering technol. These include: (a) stream and carbon dioxide reforming or partial oxidn. of methane to form carbon monoxide and hydrogen, followed by Fischer-Tropsch chem., (b) the direct oxidn. of methane to methanol and formaldehyde, (c) oxidative coupling of methane to ethylene, and (d) direct conversion to aroms. and hydrogen in the absence of oxygen. Each alternative has its own set of limitations; however, economical sepn. is common to all with the most important issues being the sepn. of oxygen from air and the sepn. of hydrogen or hydrocarbons from dil. product streams. Extensive utilization of methane for the prodn. of fuels and chems. appears to be near, but current economic uncertainties limit the amt. of research activity and the implementation of emerging technologies.

The emission of greenhouse gases (GHGs) is a major air pollution issue that affects climate change across the globe. Methane (CH4), behind carbon dioxide (CO2), is the second most abundant GHGs that neg. impact the atm. layer. Many studies have been conducted to identify a method for reducing the concn. of methane in the atm. Converting methane to alternative forms source of energy, such as methanol, is a preferred method for methane redn. This review aims to present an overview of recent literature that focuses on conversion of methane to methanol, with a focus primarily on the manufg. systems and processes used in this conversion. Basic descriptions are given of several relevant technologies for converting methane to methanol and their characteristics, including conventional catalytic processes, plasma technol., photo-catalysts, supercrit. water processes, biol. processes and other processes. All of these options are feasible for use in the conversion process of methane to methanol.

Direct catalytic methane functionalization, a dream reaction, is typically characterized by relatively low catalyst activities. This also holds for the η2-(2,2'-bipyrimidyl)dichloroplatinum(II) [(bpym)PtCl2, 1] catalyst which oxidizes methane to Me bisulfate in sulfuric acid. Nevertheless, it is arguably still one of the best systems for the partial oxidn. of methane reported so far. Detailed studies of the dependence of activity on the SO3 concn. and the interplay with the soly. of different platinum compds. revealed potassium tetrachloroplatinate (K2PtCl4) as an extremely active, selective, and stable catalyst, reaching turnover frequencies (TOFs) of >25,000 h-1 in 20% oleum with selectivities >98%. The TOFs are >3 orders of magnitude higher compared to the original report on (bpym)PtCl2 and easily reach or exceed those realized in com. industrial processes, such as the Cativa process for the carbonylation of methanol. Also space-time-yields are on the order of large-scale commercialized processes.

Solid catalysts for the direct low-temp. oxidn. of methane to methanol reaching high activity at high selectivity and stability over several recycling steps. The catalysts are based on high-performance polymer frameworks that are formed by the trimerization of arom. nitriles in molten ZnCl2; the materials are thermally stable up to 400° and resist strongly oxidizing conditions. A covalent triazine-based framework (CTF) with numerous bipyridyl structure units was obtained, which coordinates with Pt to form the catalysts. The Pt-CFT catalyst was tested in direct methane oxidn. in concd. sulfuric acid as oxidant. Surprisingly, the catalyst exhibits low activity in the first cycle, reaching TON of only 26, which increases to above 250 for subsequent cycles. The nature of the activation process is not yet fully clear but may be related to rearrangement of Pt species within the CTF.

The development of a catalytic, one-step route for the oxidn. of methane to methanol remains one of the greatest challenges within catalysis. Of particular importance is the need to develop an efficient route that proceeds under mild reaction conditions so as to avoid deeper oxidn. and the economic limitations of the currently practiced syngas route. Recently, it was demonstrated that a copper- and iron-contg. zeolite is an efficient catalyst for such a one-step process. The catalyst in question (Cu-Fe-ZSM-5) is capable of selectively transforming methane to methanol in an aq. medium with hydrogen peroxide as the terminal oxidant. Nevertheless, despite its high activity and unparalleled methanol selectivity, the origin of its activity and the precise nature of its active species are not yet fully understood. Through a combination of catalytic and spectroscopic studies, we hereby demonstrate that extraframework Fe species are the active component of the catalyst for methane oxidn., although the speciation of these sites from synthesis to catalysis significantly alters the obsd. activity and selectivity. The analogies and differences between this system and other iron-contg. zeolite-catalyzed processes, such as N2O-mediated benzene hydroxylation, are also considered.

Direct conversion of methane to methanol using oxygen is experiencing renewed interest owing to the availability of new natural gas resources. Copper-exchanged zeolites such as mordenite and ZSM-5 have shown encouraging results, and di- and tri-copper species were suggested as active sites. Recently, small eight-membered ring (8MR) zeolites including SSZ-13, -16, and -39 were active for methane oxidn., but the active sites and reaction mechanisms in these 8MR zeolites are not known. In this work, we use d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. to systematically evaluate monocopper species as active sites for the partial methane oxidn. reaction in Cu-exchanged SSZ-13. On the basis of kinetic and thermodn. arguments, we suggest that [CuIIOH]+ species in the 8MR are responsible for the exptl. obsd. activity. Our results successfully explain the available spectroscopic data and exptl. observations including (i) the necessity of water for methanol extn. and (ii) the effect of Si/Al ratio on the catalyst activity. Monocopper species have not yet been suggested as an active site for the partial methane oxidn. reaction, and our results suggest that [CuIIOH]+ active site may provide complementary routes for methane activation in zeolites in addn. to the known [Cu-O-Cu]2+ and Cu3O3 motifs.

Oxidation of ethane to ethanol by N2O in a metal-organic framework with coordinatively unsaturated iron(II) sites
Xiao, Dianne J.; Bloch, Eric D.; Mason, Jarad A.; Queen, Wendy L.; Hudson, Matthew R.; Planas, Nora; Borycz, Joshua; Dzubak, Allison L.; Verma, Pragya; Lee, Kyuho; Bonino, Francesca; Crocella, Valentina; Yano, Junko; Bordiga, Silvia; Truhlar, Donald G.; Gagliardi, Laura; Brown, Craig M.; Long, Jeffrey R.

Enzymic haem and non-haem high-valent iron-oxo species are known to activate strong C-H bonds, yet duplicating this reactivity in a synthetic system remains a formidable challenge. Although instability of the terminal iron-oxo moiety is perhaps the foremost obstacle, steric and electronic factors also limit the activity of previously reported mononuclear iron(IV)-oxo compds. In particular, although nature's non-haem iron(IV)-oxo compds. possess high-spin S = 2 ground states, this electronic configuration has proved difficult to achieve in a mol. species. These challenges may be mitigated within metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) that feature site-isolated iron centers in a constrained, weak-field ligand environment. Here, we show that the metal-org. framework Fe2(dobdc) (dobdc4- = 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) and its magnesium-dild. analog, Fe0.1Mg1.9(dobdc), are able to activate the C-H bonds of ethane and convert it into ethanol and acetaldehyde using nitrous oxide as the terminal oxidant. Electronic structure calcns. indicate that the active oxidant is likely to be a high-spin S = 2 iron(IV)-oxo species.

The catalytic properties of the metal-org. framework Fe2(dobdc), contg. open Fe(II) sites, include hydroxylation of phenol by pure Fe2(dobdc) and hydroxylation of ethane by its magnesium-dild. analog, Fe0.1Mg1.9(dobdc). In earlier work, the latter reaction was proposed to occur through a redox mechanism involving the generation of an iron(IV)-oxo species, which is an intermediate that is also obsd. or postulated (depending on the case) in some heme and nonheme enzymes and their model complexes. In the present work, we present a detailed mechanism by which the catalytic material, Fe0.1Mg1.9(dobdc), activates the strong C-H bonds of ethane. Kohn-Sham d. functional and multireference wave function calcns. have been performed to characterize the electronic structure of key species. We show that the catalytic nonheme-Fe hydroxylation of the strong C-H bond of ethane proceeds by a quintet single-state σ-attack pathway after the formation of highly reactive iron-oxo intermediate. The mechanistic pathway involves three key transition states, with the highest activation barrier for the transfer of oxygen from N2O to the Fe(II) center. The uncatalyzed reaction, where nitrous oxide directly oxidizes ethane to ethanol is found to have an activation barrier of 280 kJ/mol, in contrast to 82 kJ/mol for the slowest step in the iron(IV)-oxo catalytic mechanism. The energetics of the C-H bond activation steps of ethane and methane are also compared. Dehydrogenation and dissocn. pathways that can compete with the formation of ethanol were shown to involve higher barriers than the hydroxylation pathway.

We performed ONIOM QM/MM calcns. to understand how ethane is hydroxylated and ethanol is converted to acetaldehyde by an oxoiron(IV) species generated within an iron-contg. metal-org. framework called Fe-MOF-74. The calcns. showed that the ethane hydroxylation proceeds via a high-spin rebound mechanism. The conversion of ethanol into acetaldehyde should occur more favorably via H-abstraction from the O-H bond than via C-H cleavage, although the O-H bond of ethanol is stronger than the C(1)-H bond. This trend can be rationalized by the effect of proton-coupled electron transfer, which stabilizes the transition state for O-H cleavage.

The solid acid catalyst was characterized using a variety of different techniques, including x-ray powder diffraction (x-ray diffraction), SEM, TEM, thermogravimetric anal. (TGA), Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FT-IR), at. absorption spectrophotometry (AAS), and nitrogen physisorption measurements. Quant. conversion was achieved under mild conditions without the need for an inert atm. The MOF-5 catalyst could be facilely sepd. from the reaction mixt., and could be reused several times without significant degrdn. in catalytic activity. Furthermore, no contribution from homogeneous catalysis of active acid species leaching into reaction soln. was detected.

Generalized gradient approxns. (GGA's) for the exchange-correlation energy improve upon the local spin d. (LSD) description of atoms, mols., and solids. We present a simple derivation of a simple GGA, in which all parameters (other than those in LSD) are fundamental consts. Only general features of the detailed construction underlying the Perdew-Wang 1991 (PW91) GGA are invoked. Improvements over PW91 include an accurate description of the linear response of the uniform electron gas, correct behavior under uniform scaling, and a smoother potential.

The M06 suite of density functionals for main group thermochemistry, thermochemical kinetics, noncovalent interactions, excited states, and transition elements: two new functionals and systematic testing of four M06-class functionals and 12 other functionals
Zhao, Yan; Truhlar, Donald G.

),

; ISSN:

We present two new hybrid meta exchange-correlation functionals, called M06 and M06-2X. The M06 functional is parametrized including both transition metals and nonmetals, whereas the M06-2X functional is a high-nonlocality functional with double the amt. of nonlocal exchange (2X), and it is parametrized only for nonmetals. The functionals, along with the previously published M06-L local functional and the M06-HF full-Hartree-Fock functionals, constitute the M06 suite of complementary functionals. We assess these four functionals by comparing their performance to that of 12 other functionals and Hartree-Fock theory for 403 energetic data in 29 diverse databases, including ten databases for thermochem., four databases for kinetics, eight databases for noncovalent interactions, three databases for transition metal bonding, one database for metal atom excitation energies, and three databases for mol. excitation energies. We also illustrate the performance of these 17 methods for three databases contg. 40 bond lengths and for databases contg. 38 vibrational frequencies and 15 vibrational zero point energies. We recommend the M06-2X functional for applications involving main-group thermochem., kinetics, noncovalent interactions, and electronic excitation energies to valence and Rydberg states. We recommend the M06 functional for application in organometallic and inorganometallic chem. and for noncovalent interactions.

Gaussian basis sets of quadruple zeta valence quality for Rb-Rn are presented, as well as bases of split valence and triple zeta valence quality for H-Rn. A large set of more than 300 mols. representing (nearly) all elements-except lanthanides-in their common oxidn. states was used to assess the quality of the bases all across the periodic table. Quantities investigated were atomization energies, dipole moments and structure parameters for Hartree-Fock, d. functional theory and correlated methods, for which we had chosen Moller-Plesset perturbation theory as an example. Finally recommendations are given which type of basis set is used best for a certain level of theory and a desired quality of results.

A series of auxiliary basis sets to fit Coulomb potentials for the elements H to Rn (except lanthanides) is presented. For each element only one auxiliary basis set is needed to approx. Coulomb energies in conjunction with orbital basis sets of split valence, triple zeta valence and quadruple zeta valence quality with errors of typically below ca. 0.15 kJ mol-1 per atom; this was demonstrated in conjunction with the recently developed orbital basis sets of types def2-SV(P), def2-TZVP and def2-QZVPP for a large set of small mols. representing (nearly) each element in all of its common oxidn. states. These auxiliary bases are slightly more than three times larger than orbital bases of split valence quality. Compared to non-approximated treatments, computation times for the Coulomb part are reduced by a factor of ca. 8 for def2-SV(P) orbital bases, ca. 25 for def2-TZVP and ca. 100 for def2-QZVPP orbital bases.

Natural gas (NG) is a naturally gaseous hydrocarbon mixt. that is formed under the earth's surface. NG is considered to be the cleanest fossil fuel and is a safe source of energy when transported, stored and used. The primary constituent of NG is methane, it may also contain (C2+ hydrocarbons, N2, CO2, He, H2S, and noble gases) according to its origin. Different gas processing technologies can be employed to remove constituents other than methane. Due to importance of NG as a fuel and the increasing global demand of it, this article reviews the fundamentals of NG origin, compn., and processing.

A review with 45 refs. The very large reserves of methane, which often are found in remote regions, could serve as a feedstock for the prodn. of chems. and as a source of energy well into the 21st century. Although methane currently is being used in such important applications as the heating of homes and the generation of hydrogen for ammonia synthesis, its potential for the prodn. of ethylene or liq. hydrocarbon fuels has not been fully realized. A no. of strategies are being explored at levels that range from fundamental science to engineering technol. These include: (a) stream and carbon dioxide reforming or partial oxidn. of methane to form carbon monoxide and hydrogen, followed by Fischer-Tropsch chem., (b) the direct oxidn. of methane to methanol and formaldehyde, (c) oxidative coupling of methane to ethylene, and (d) direct conversion to aroms. and hydrogen in the absence of oxygen. Each alternative has its own set of limitations; however, economical sepn. is common to all with the most important issues being the sepn. of oxygen from air and the sepn. of hydrogen or hydrocarbons from dil. product streams. Extensive utilization of methane for the prodn. of fuels and chems. appears to be near, but current economic uncertainties limit the amt. of research activity and the implementation of emerging technologies.

The emission of greenhouse gases (GHGs) is a major air pollution issue that affects climate change across the globe. Methane (CH4), behind carbon dioxide (CO2), is the second most abundant GHGs that neg. impact the atm. layer. Many studies have been conducted to identify a method for reducing the concn. of methane in the atm. Converting methane to alternative forms source of energy, such as methanol, is a preferred method for methane redn. This review aims to present an overview of recent literature that focuses on conversion of methane to methanol, with a focus primarily on the manufg. systems and processes used in this conversion. Basic descriptions are given of several relevant technologies for converting methane to methanol and their characteristics, including conventional catalytic processes, plasma technol., photo-catalysts, supercrit. water processes, biol. processes and other processes. All of these options are feasible for use in the conversion process of methane to methanol.

Direct catalytic methane functionalization, a dream reaction, is typically characterized by relatively low catalyst activities. This also holds for the η2-(2,2'-bipyrimidyl)dichloroplatinum(II) [(bpym)PtCl2, 1] catalyst which oxidizes methane to Me bisulfate in sulfuric acid. Nevertheless, it is arguably still one of the best systems for the partial oxidn. of methane reported so far. Detailed studies of the dependence of activity on the SO3 concn. and the interplay with the soly. of different platinum compds. revealed potassium tetrachloroplatinate (K2PtCl4) as an extremely active, selective, and stable catalyst, reaching turnover frequencies (TOFs) of >25,000 h-1 in 20% oleum with selectivities >98%. The TOFs are >3 orders of magnitude higher compared to the original report on (bpym)PtCl2 and easily reach or exceed those realized in com. industrial processes, such as the Cativa process for the carbonylation of methanol. Also space-time-yields are on the order of large-scale commercialized processes.

Solid catalysts for the direct low-temp. oxidn. of methane to methanol reaching high activity at high selectivity and stability over several recycling steps. The catalysts are based on high-performance polymer frameworks that are formed by the trimerization of arom. nitriles in molten ZnCl2; the materials are thermally stable up to 400° and resist strongly oxidizing conditions. A covalent triazine-based framework (CTF) with numerous bipyridyl structure units was obtained, which coordinates with Pt to form the catalysts. The Pt-CFT catalyst was tested in direct methane oxidn. in concd. sulfuric acid as oxidant. Surprisingly, the catalyst exhibits low activity in the first cycle, reaching TON of only 26, which increases to above 250 for subsequent cycles. The nature of the activation process is not yet fully clear but may be related to rearrangement of Pt species within the CTF.

The development of a catalytic, one-step route for the oxidn. of methane to methanol remains one of the greatest challenges within catalysis. Of particular importance is the need to develop an efficient route that proceeds under mild reaction conditions so as to avoid deeper oxidn. and the economic limitations of the currently practiced syngas route. Recently, it was demonstrated that a copper- and iron-contg. zeolite is an efficient catalyst for such a one-step process. The catalyst in question (Cu-Fe-ZSM-5) is capable of selectively transforming methane to methanol in an aq. medium with hydrogen peroxide as the terminal oxidant. Nevertheless, despite its high activity and unparalleled methanol selectivity, the origin of its activity and the precise nature of its active species are not yet fully understood. Through a combination of catalytic and spectroscopic studies, we hereby demonstrate that extraframework Fe species are the active component of the catalyst for methane oxidn., although the speciation of these sites from synthesis to catalysis significantly alters the obsd. activity and selectivity. The analogies and differences between this system and other iron-contg. zeolite-catalyzed processes, such as N2O-mediated benzene hydroxylation, are also considered.

Direct conversion of methane to methanol using oxygen is experiencing renewed interest owing to the availability of new natural gas resources. Copper-exchanged zeolites such as mordenite and ZSM-5 have shown encouraging results, and di- and tri-copper species were suggested as active sites. Recently, small eight-membered ring (8MR) zeolites including SSZ-13, -16, and -39 were active for methane oxidn., but the active sites and reaction mechanisms in these 8MR zeolites are not known. In this work, we use d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. to systematically evaluate monocopper species as active sites for the partial methane oxidn. reaction in Cu-exchanged SSZ-13. On the basis of kinetic and thermodn. arguments, we suggest that [CuIIOH]+ species in the 8MR are responsible for the exptl. obsd. activity. Our results successfully explain the available spectroscopic data and exptl. observations including (i) the necessity of water for methanol extn. and (ii) the effect of Si/Al ratio on the catalyst activity. Monocopper species have not yet been suggested as an active site for the partial methane oxidn. reaction, and our results suggest that [CuIIOH]+ active site may provide complementary routes for methane activation in zeolites in addn. to the known [Cu-O-Cu]2+ and Cu3O3 motifs.

Enzymic haem and non-haem high-valent iron-oxo species are known to activate strong C-H bonds, yet duplicating this reactivity in a synthetic system remains a formidable challenge. Although instability of the terminal iron-oxo moiety is perhaps the foremost obstacle, steric and electronic factors also limit the activity of previously reported mononuclear iron(IV)-oxo compds. In particular, although nature's non-haem iron(IV)-oxo compds. possess high-spin S = 2 ground states, this electronic configuration has proved difficult to achieve in a mol. species. These challenges may be mitigated within metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) that feature site-isolated iron centers in a constrained, weak-field ligand environment. Here, we show that the metal-org. framework Fe2(dobdc) (dobdc4- = 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) and its magnesium-dild. analog, Fe0.1Mg1.9(dobdc), are able to activate the C-H bonds of ethane and convert it into ethanol and acetaldehyde using nitrous oxide as the terminal oxidant. Electronic structure calcns. indicate that the active oxidant is likely to be a high-spin S = 2 iron(IV)-oxo species.

The catalytic properties of the metal-org. framework Fe2(dobdc), contg. open Fe(II) sites, include hydroxylation of phenol by pure Fe2(dobdc) and hydroxylation of ethane by its magnesium-dild. analog, Fe0.1Mg1.9(dobdc). In earlier work, the latter reaction was proposed to occur through a redox mechanism involving the generation of an iron(IV)-oxo species, which is an intermediate that is also obsd. or postulated (depending on the case) in some heme and nonheme enzymes and their model complexes. In the present work, we present a detailed mechanism by which the catalytic material, Fe0.1Mg1.9(dobdc), activates the strong C-H bonds of ethane. Kohn-Sham d. functional and multireference wave function calcns. have been performed to characterize the electronic structure of key species. We show that the catalytic nonheme-Fe hydroxylation of the strong C-H bond of ethane proceeds by a quintet single-state σ-attack pathway after the formation of highly reactive iron-oxo intermediate. The mechanistic pathway involves three key transition states, with the highest activation barrier for the transfer of oxygen from N2O to the Fe(II) center. The uncatalyzed reaction, where nitrous oxide directly oxidizes ethane to ethanol is found to have an activation barrier of 280 kJ/mol, in contrast to 82 kJ/mol for the slowest step in the iron(IV)-oxo catalytic mechanism. The energetics of the C-H bond activation steps of ethane and methane are also compared. Dehydrogenation and dissocn. pathways that can compete with the formation of ethanol were shown to involve higher barriers than the hydroxylation pathway.

MOF-5 as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for Friedel-Crafts alkylation reactions
Phan, Nam T. S.; Le, Ky K. A.; Phan, Tuan D.
Applied Catalysis, A: General

A highly porous metal-org. framework (MOF-5) was synthesized by a solvothermal method, and used as an efficient heterogeneous acid catalyst for Friedel-Crafts alkylation reactions. The solid acid catalyst was characterized using a variety of different techniques, including x-ray powder diffraction (x-ray diffraction), SEM, TEM, thermogravimetric anal. (TGA), Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FT-IR), at. absorption spectrophotometry (AAS), and nitrogen physisorption measurements. Quant. conversion was achieved under mild conditions without the need for an inert atm. The MOF-5 catalyst could be facilely sepd. from the reaction mixt., and could be reused several times without significant degrdn. in catalytic activity. Furthermore, no contribution from homogeneous catalysis of active acid species leaching into reaction soln. was detected.

Perdew, John P.; Burke, Kieron; Ernzerhof, Matthias
Physical Review Letters

Generalized gradient approxns. (GGA's) for the exchange-correlation energy improve upon the local spin d. (LSD) description of atoms, mols., and solids. We present a simple derivation of a simple GGA, in which all parameters (other than those in LSD) are fundamental consts. Only general features of the detailed construction underlying the Perdew-Wang 1991 (PW91) GGA are invoked. Improvements over PW91 include an accurate description of the linear response of the uniform electron gas, correct behavior under uniform scaling, and a smoother potential.

The M06 suite of density functionals for main group thermochemistry, thermochemical kinetics, noncovalent interactions, excited states, and transition elements: two new functionals and systematic testing of four M06-class functionals and 12 other functionals
Zhao, Yan; Truhlar, Donald G.
Theoretical Chemistry Accounts
(
2008
),
120
(
1-3
),
215-241
CODEN:
TCACFW
; ISSN:
1432-881X
.
(
Springer GmbH
)
We present two new hybrid meta exchange-correlation functionals, called M06 and M06-2X. The M06 functional is parametrized including both transition metals and nonmetals, whereas the M06-2X functional is a high-nonlocality functional with double the amt. of nonlocal exchange (2X), and it is parametrized only for nonmetals. The functionals, along with the previously published M06-L local functional and the M06-HF full-Hartree-Fock functionals, constitute the M06 suite of complementary functionals. We assess these four functionals by comparing their performance to that of 12 other functionals and Hartree-Fock theory for 403 energetic data in 29 diverse databases, including ten databases for thermochem., four databases for kinetics, eight databases for noncovalent interactions, three databases for transition metal bonding, one database for metal atom excitation energies, and three databases for mol. excitation energies. We also illustrate the performance of these 17 methods for three databases contg. 40 bond lengths and for databases contg. 38 vibrational frequencies and 15 vibrational zero point energies. We recommend the M06-2X functional for applications involving main-group thermochem., kinetics, noncovalent interactions, and electronic excitation energies to valence and Rydberg states. We recommend the M06 functional for application in organometallic and inorganometallic chem. and for noncovalent interactions.

Balanced basis sets of split valence, triple zeta valence and quadruple zeta valence quality for H to Rn: Design and assessment of accuracy
Weigend, Florian; Ahlrichs, Reinhart
Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics
(

Gaussian basis sets of quadruple zeta valence quality for Rb-Rn are presented, as well as bases of split valence and triple zeta valence quality for H-Rn. The latter were obtained by (partly) modifying bases developed previously. A large set of more than 300 mols. representing (nearly) all elements-except lanthanides-in their common oxidn. states was used to assess the quality of the bases all across the periodic table. Quantities investigated were atomization energies, dipole moments and structure parameters for Hartree-Fock, d. functional theory and correlated methods, for which we had chosen Moller-Plesset perturbation theory as an example. Finally recommendations are given which type of basis set is used best for a certain level of theory and a desired quality of results.

Accurate Coulomb-fitting basis sets for H to Rn
Weigend, Florian
Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics
(
2006
),
8
(

1057-1065
CODEN:
PPCPFQ
; ISSN:
1463-9076

Royal Society of Chemistry

A series of auxiliary basis sets to fit Coulomb potentials for the elements H to Rn (except lanthanides) is presented. For each element only one auxiliary basis set is needed to approx. Coulomb energies in conjunction with orbital basis sets of split valence, triple zeta valence and quadruple zeta valence quality with errors of typically below ca. 0.15 kJ mol-1 per atom; this was demonstrated in conjunction with the recently developed orbital basis sets of types def2-SV(P), def2-TZVP and def2-QZVPP for a large set of small mols. representing (nearly) each element in all of its common oxidn. states. These auxiliary bases are slightly more than three times larger than orbital bases of split valence quality. Compared to non-approximated treatments, computation times for the Coulomb part are reduced by a factor of ca. 8 for def2-SV(P) orbital bases, ca. 25 for def2-TZVP and ca. 100 for def2-QZVPP orbital bases.
